entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-Equity-Chan-12
entry.itemBody: The voting method that allows shareholders to cast all their votes for a single candidate is best described as:

answerFeedback.008c68f3-0e8b-4fb4-ba0f-8d92f0ec1b83: Incorrect because proxy voting is defined as shareholders may vote by proxy, which allows a designated party—such as another shareholder, a shareholder representative, or management—to vote on the shareholders’ behalf.
answerFeedback.60ea720e-d72d-4b81-aaf2-afda63c70e14: Incorrect because cumulative voting allows shareholders to direct their total voting rights to specific candidates, as opposed to statutory voting having to allocate their voting rights evenly among all candidates.
answerFeedback.ee7c3503-4cbc-4c0c-9c02-4cea5ca1a6df: Correct because cumulative voting allows shareholders to direct their total voting rights to specific candidates, as opposed to statutory voting having to allocate their voting rights evenly among all candidates.

choices.itemBody: A. proxy voting.
B. statutory voting.
C. cumulative voting.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-Equity-Coorey-01
entry.itemBody: Management is more likely to focus on short-term results instead of long-term earnings growth if a company raises equity through:

answerFeedback.7751e1a6-7340-485c-91da-6c3e1e43176a: Incorrect because by going private, management can adopt a more long-term focus and can eliminate certain costs that are necessary to operate a publicly traded company. Whereas in operating a publicly traded company, management often feels pressured to focus on short-term results (e.g., meeting quarterly sales and earnings targets from analysts biased toward near-term price performance) instead of operating the company to obtain long-term sustainable revenue and earnings growth. There are three primary types of private equity investments: venture capital, leveraged buyouts, and private investment in public equity (or PIPE).
answerFeedback.af41ed1f-63d6-490f-b193-b5e1ce14af29: Incorrect because by going private, management can adopt a more long-term focus and can eliminate certain costs that are necessary to operate a publicly traded company. Whereas in operating a publicly traded company, management often feels pressured to focus on short-term results (e.g., meeting quarterly sales and earnings targets from analysts biased toward near-term price performance) instead of operating the company to obtain long-term sustainable revenue and earnings growth. There are three primary types of private equity investments: venture capital, leveraged buyouts, and private investment in public equity (or PIPE).
answerFeedback.c85564df-4fae-4d6d-8608-f864f2eb5662: Correct because in operating a publicly traded company, management often feels pressured to focus on short-term results (e.g., meeting quarterly sales and earnings targets from analysts biased toward near-term price performance) instead of operating the company to obtain long-term sustainable revenue and earnings growth.

choices.itemBody: A. venture capital.
B. a leveraged buyout.
C. an initial public offering.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-Equity-Chan-13
entry.itemBody: Common shares that are tradeable on different stock exchanges in different currencies are best described as:

answerFeedback.8ec00a0a-e360-4422-b7d7-61ce262bce5d: Correct because a global registered share (GRS) is a common share that is traded on different stock exchanges around the world in different currencies.
answerFeedback.a0ae2f34-ec11-447d-9d93-50dfef837a37: Incorrect because a basket of listed depository receipts (BLDR), which is an exchange-traded fund (ETF) that represents a portfolio of depository receipts.
answerFeedback.b2a59bc3-4924-4a04-81d2-95a4178f7df0: Incorrect because a GDR is traded in the specified local stock exchange only. A depository receipt (DR) is a security that trades like an ordinary share on a local exchange and represents an economic interest in a foreign company. There are two types of depository receipts including Global depository receipts (GDRs).

choices.itemBody: A. global registered shares.
B. global depository receipts.
C. a basket of listed depository receipts.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-Equity-Chan-11
entry.itemBody: The book value of a company's equity is:

answerFeedback.9be62f53-39b2-4c61-824f-ae807aa3705f: Incorrect because intrinsic value is often defined as the present value of all expected future cash flows of the asset.
answerFeedback.dbe41322-53f0-4f31-ba7b-0ef8b2fcf7f4: Correct because the book value of a company’s equity is the difference between its total assets and total liabilities.
answerFeedback.f57caef7-78ac-41f6-b6e3-23be8bc64d13: Incorrect because this the total market value of equity (or market capitalization) computed as the number of shares outstanding multiplied by the market price per share.

choices.itemBody: A. the present value of its future cash flows.
B. the difference between its total assets and total liabilities.
C. its share price multiplied by the number of outstanding shares.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-05203
entry.itemBody: All else being equal, which of the following preference shares pays the lowest dividend?

answerFeedback.bb873545-a54a-4435-af47-face2e5e2c22: Correct because from an investor's point of view, putable common or preference shares are less risky than their callable or non-callable counterparts because they give the investor the option to sell the shares to the issuer at a pre-determined price. As a result, putable shares generally pay a lower dividend than non-putable shares.
answerFeedback.d61636bb-17d7-4607-b13a-3c2630a5c447: Incorrect because from an investor's point of view, putable common or preference shares are less risky than their callable or non-callable counterparts because they give the investor the option to sell the shares to the issuer at a pre-determined price. The lower risk of putables shares results in a lower dividend than non-callable shares.
answerFeedback.e43ccf7e-7d2b-4296-a1b7-d4c63f54715f: Incorrect because callable common or preference shares are riskier than their non-callable counterparts because the issuer has the option to redeem the shares at a pre-determined price. Callable shares generally pay a higher dividend to compensate investors for the risk that the shares could be called in the future.

choices.itemBody: A. Putable
B. Callable
C. Non-callable

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-08428
entry.itemBody: Which of the following is least likely to directly affect a company's book value?

answerFeedback.90212957-f69c-4800-abe2-bdd44b6f6465: Incorrect because changes in a company's net income directly affect the book value of the company.
answerFeedback.c003909e-04dc-4635-ba29-c63220f84288: Correct because a company's book value is not directly affected by investor estimates.
answerFeedback.d51a4bc7-8830-4175-9e1e-16fd46c85ace: Incorrect because purchases by the company of its own shares directly affect the book value of the company.

choices.itemBody: A. Changes in the company's net income
B. Purchases by the company of its own shares
C. Investor estimates of the company's future cash flows

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-09847
entry.itemBody: A company's ROE most likely decreases if shareholders' equity increases at:

answerFeedback.0428fd2b-112f-49c4-b760-cdf297e45002: Correct because ROE can increase if net income increases at a faster rate than shareholders' equity or if net income decreases at a slower rate than shareholders' equity.
answerFeedback.a85b95ad-04ca-4885-ac77-d1c69ef38a3c: Incorrect because ROE can increase if net income increases at a faster rate than shareholders' equity or if net income decreases at a slower rate than shareholders' equity. If shareholder equity increases at the same rate as net income, then ROE will remain the same and not increase.
answerFeedback.deb69ccc-7cc2-4605-acac-26361ba1ade9: Incorrect because ROE can increase if net income increases at a faster rate than shareholders' equity or if net income decreases at a slower rate than shareholders' equity. If shareholder equity increases at a faster rate than net income increases, then ROE will decrease, not increase.

choices.itemBody: A. a lower rate than net income.
B. the same rate as net income.
C. a higher rate than net income.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-06978
entry.itemBody: Global depository receipts are most likely:

answerFeedback.55fc29d9-e76d-4288-873f-f7ced6bd3b67: Incorrect because GDRs cannot be listed on US exchanges.
answerFeedback.95e99450-dbc7-4f40-9ef5-6cf09ef1952d: Incorrect because the issuing company selects the exchange where the GDR is to be traded based on such factors as investors' familiarity with the company or the existence of a large international investor base. The majority of GDRs are denominated in US dollars, although the number of GDRs denominated in pound sterling and euros is increasing. While it is possible that the GDR is denominated in the currency of the issuing company, this is not the most likely case among the choices given.
answerFeedback.bc45917e-2aaa-4ebb-b8ad-736dd73c1e49: Correct because a global depository receipt (GDR) is issued outside of the company's home country and outside of the United States.

choices.itemBody: A. issued outside the US.
B. listed on US exchanges.
C. denominated in the currency of the issuing company.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-05317
entry.itemBody: If investors believe a company has a large number of positive net present value investment opportunities, the company's book value will most likely be:

answerFeedback.08945f24-faf3-4e89-a08c-4dcdee70857c: Correct because the market value of the company's equity reflects investor's collective assessment and expectations about the company's future cash flows generated by its positive net present value investment opportunities. If investors believe that the company has a large number of these future cash flow-generating investment opportunities, the market value of the company's equity will exceed its book value.
answerFeedback.e489496b-5fdd-4900-9abe-94afdcc6b33a: Incorrect because if investors believe that the company has a large number of these future cash flow-generating investment opportunities, the market value of the company's equity will exceed its book value; book value will not be the same or greater than market value.
answerFeedback.e6801c8e-e1c1-49cf-9539-4fc6957c3f2c: Incorrect because if investors believe that the company has a large number of these future cash flow-generating investment opportunities, the market value of the company's equity will exceed its book value; book value will not be the same or greater than market value.

choices.itemBody: A. less than the market value.
B. equal to the market value.
C. greater than the market value.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-04612
entry.itemBody: Investors' minimum required rate of return on a company's stock is most directly measured by the:

answerFeedback.457dc04b-9925-4efd-8149-bc51759f11e2: Correct because two models commonly used to estimate a company's cost of equity (or investors' minimum required rate of return) are the dividend discount model (DDM) and the capital asset pricing model (CAPM).
answerFeedback.567ed7f9-dc40-46cb-83a6-f965adf3e9a3: Incorrect because the WACC represents the minimum required rate of return that the company must earn on its long-term investments to satisfy all providers of capital. WACC would typically include the cost of debt and hence is not the minimum return on stock.
answerFeedback.5990e09d-79fa-4c95-ac80-f72d753e1eb0: Incorrect because ROE is an accounting measure of how effectively a company earns profits on invested equity and is not used to measure investors' required return.

choices.itemBody: A. CAPM.
B. company's ROE.
C. company's WACC.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-02461
entry.itemBody: Which of the following methods of raising capital most likely provides mezzanine financing to early-stage companies?

answerFeedback.0256babb-9365-4243-a3fe-228d82dc7739: Correct because venture capital investments provide ‘seed' or start-up capital, early-stage financing, or mezzanine financing to companies that are in the early stages of development and require additional capital for expansion.
answerFeedback.e10d65fe-427c-48b8-9b84-9fa9c7316d78: Incorrect because private investment in public equity (PIPE) is generally sought by a public company that is in need of additional capital quickly and is willing to sell a sizeable ownership position to a private investor or investor group. It is not a mechanism to provide financing to early-stage companies.
answerFeedback.e198411f-bd50-4f02-ab4a-d2aa93c7797e: Incorrect because an initial public offering (IPO) occurs when a start-up company first goes public. An IPO is the first issuance of common shares to the public by a formerly private corporation.

choices.itemBody: A. Venture capital
B. Initial public offering (IPO)
C. Private investment in public equity (PIPE)

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-03288
entry.itemBody: Which of the following types of preference shares entitles shareholders to receive an additional dividend if the company's profits exceed a pre-specified level?

answerFeedback.934d0dba-185e-403c-bf4e-a464798cf46a: Incorrect because convertible preference shares entitle shareholders to convert their shares into a specified number of common shares. They do not allow shareholders to get an additional dividend on higher profits.
answerFeedback.eab1e9ea-2851-4983-9d16-4e19d927fba0: Correct because participating preference shares entitle the shareholders to receive the standard preferred dividend plus the opportunity to receive an additional dividend if the company's profits exceed a pre- specified level.
answerFeedback.fd9c12a4-0760-4a09-862a-9b5c31b75ebb: Incorrect because cumulative preference shares have dividends that accrue if the company does not pay a dividend for a time and these dividends must be paid in full before common dividends are paid. They do not allow shareholders to get an additional dividend on higher profits.

choices.itemBody: A. Cumulative
B. Convertible
C. Participating

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-01227
entry.itemBody: Management actions most directly affect a company's:

answerFeedback.3850adea-77f2-49c6-8657-7e97e05d1a77: Incorrect because management actions can only indirectly affect the market value of its equity. The market value reflects the collective and differing expectations of investors concerning the company's cash flows.
answerFeedback.a1a89327-14e2-46f9-8555-cce6bf81694f: Correct because management actions can directly affect the book value of the company (by increasing net income or by selling or purchasing its own shares).
answerFeedback.a5a42fa2-7d86-497c-82c2-f6cfd4ba4786: Incorrect because intrinsic value is an investor's subjective estimate of the discounted value of the cash that can be taken out of a business during its remaining life. It is not directly affected by management actions.

choices.itemBody: A. book value.
B. market value.
C. intrinsic value.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-01296
entry.itemBody: The discounted value of a company's future projected cash flows is best described as its:

answerFeedback.1dcecca5-11dd-4006-afac-0d6c9fefc249: Incorrect because a company's market value is the market price per share times the number of outstanding shares, not the present value of future projected cash flows.
answerFeedback.3c48a0b0-eaca-4588-b87b-db1a222d5d0f: Incorrect because a company's book value is the difference between its total assets and total liabilities, not the present value of future projected cash flows.
answerFeedback.6f94544d-a31d-4e76-893d-9f01c15fd498: Correct because the company's intrinsic value is the present value of its future projected cash flows.

choices.itemBody: A. book value.
B. market value.
C. intrinsic value.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-02944
entry.itemBody: Which of the following shareholder groups benefits the most by using cumulative voting?

answerFeedback.0ce0dca9-590d-424a-b271-c1cb49f40187: Correct because cumulative voting allows shareholders to direct their total voting rights to specific candidates, as opposed to having to allocate their voting rights evenly among all candidates. The key benefit to cumulative voting is that it allows shareholders with a small number of shares to apply all of their votes to one candidate, thus providing the opportunity for a higher level of representation on the board than would be allowed under statutory voting.
answerFeedback.907f200a-2017-4923-a46f-5ebe6155e4fd: Incorrect because cumulative voting reduces the advantage held by shareholders with a large number of shares. Under cumulative voting, total voting rights are based on the number of shares owned multiplied by the number of board directors being elected. Shareholders can cast all votes in favor of a single candidate or spread them across the candidates in any proportion. While shareholders with a large number of shares still have more votes than shareholders with a small number of shares, their ability to control the board representation now depends on how their votes are proportionately distributed relative to the votes cast by shareholders with a small number of shares.
answerFeedback.dd9f9d7f-5448-47da-a611-96eb55fdf7d6: Incorrect because preference shareholders do not share in the operating performance of the company and generally do not have voting rights. Furthermore, cumulative voting should not be confused with cumulative preference shares which are shares that accrue dividends that must be paid in full before dividends on common shares can be paid.

choices.itemBody: A. Preference shareholders
B. Shareholders with a large number of shares
C. Shareholders with a small number of shares

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2022.08-Equity-Tyler-05
entry.itemBody: In a management buyout transaction, a public company is most likely privatized through the:

answerFeedback.422f9a6f-f80f-42b0-8270-50c2f438a522:
Correct because a leveraged buyout (LBO) occurs when a group of investors (such as the company’s management or a private equity partnership) uses a large amount of debt to purchase all of the outstanding common shares of a publicly traded company. In cases where the group of investors acquiring the company is primarily comprised of the company’s existing management, the transaction is referred to as a management buyout (MBO). After the shares are purchased, they cease to trade on an exchange and the investor group takes full control of the company. In other words, the company
is taken “private” or has been privatized.
answerFeedback.7f5fd5ea-147f-46a8-b465-4e199a281b8d: Incorrect because an LBO most likely involves the purchase of publicly-listed shares, not the issue of new shares. A leveraged buyout (LBO) occurs when a group of investors (such as the company’s management or a private equity partnership) uses a large amount of debt to purchase all of the outstanding common shares of a publicly traded company. In cases where the group of investors acquiring the company is primarily comprised of the company’s existing management, the transaction is referred to as a management buyout (MBO).
answerFeedback.ef9da17e-e77d-4ec9-ae50-4b8ad5e6bc2c: Incorrect because in a management buyout, management is the purchaser of shares rather than the issuer of shares. In cases where the group of investors acquiring the company is primarily comprised of the company’s existing management, the transaction is referred to as a management buyout (MBO).

choices.itemBody: A. issue of new shares to management.
B. issue of new shares by management.
C. purchase of publicly listed shares by management.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-11216
entry.itemBody: If a company raises equity capital in order to continue as a going concern rather than fund revenue-generating activities, the capital is most likely used to:

answerFeedback.12abfe7c-4d3c-4f91-b3b7-1075599dd261: Incorrect because the primary goal of raising capital is to finance the company's revenue-generating activities. In most cases, the capital that is raised is used to finance the purchase of long-lived assets.
answerFeedback.6bbea08c-2d1d-4b91-9747-dca8562d6f67: Incorrect because the primary goal of raising capital is to finance the company's revenue-generating activities. In most cases, the capital that is raised is used to finance the acquisition of other companies.
answerFeedback.984b7352-09ee-45bc-8cb6-56232dd192f6: Correct because a company may be forced to raise capital to ensure that it continues to operate as a going concern. In these cases, capital is raised to fulfill regulatory requirements, improve capital adequacy ratios, or to ensure that debt covenants are met.

choices.itemBody: A. acquire other companies.
B. purchase long-lived assets.
C. ensure that debt covenants are met.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-01231
entry.itemBody: Preference shares that provide the investor with an opportunity to share in the profits of the company are best described as:

answerFeedback.50eca146-bbb1-49ed-920c-773765180901: Incorrect because neither non-cumulative nor cumulative preference shares do not share in the operating performance of the company and do not allow investors the opportunity to share in the profits of the company.
answerFeedback.5450d2c1-5036-45a9-989a-41dcffb73adc: Incorrect because neither non-cumulative nor cumulative preference shares do not share in the operating performance of the company and do not allow investors the opportunity to share in the profits of the company.
answerFeedback.5925ef1b-0bbb-4d27-b539-6851d3f72cd6: Correct because convertible preference shares allow investors the opportunity to share in the profits of the company.

choices.itemBody: A. cumulative.
B. convertible.
C. non-cumulative.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-09431
entry.itemBody: Common shares most likely rank above preference shares with respect to:

answerFeedback.b0235726-c225-46c8-b410-dcee0c379811: Correct because preference shareholders generally do not share in the operating performance of the company and do not have any voting rights.
answerFeedback.d91df9d3-31f2-4efd-bf67-ed72c4b638d5: Incorrect because preference shares (or preferred stock) rank above common shares with respect to the payment of dividends and the distribution of the company's net assets upon liquidation.
answerFeedback.e94a8966-49bc-45f7-9928-db3d0617382b: Incorrect because preference shares (or preferred stock) rank above common shares with respect to the payment of dividends and the distribution of the company's net assets upon liquidation.

choices.itemBody: A. voting rights.
B. the payment of dividends.
C. the distribution of the company's net assets upon liquidation.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-05835
entry.itemBody: All else being equal, convertible preference shares most likely:

answerFeedback.61f505fb-1d13-4a14-8aec-7e315c76a353: Incorrect because convertible preference shares are less volatile than the underlying common shares because the dividend payments are known and more stable.
answerFeedback.cc566b4d-f48c-4286-8106-418d41d07118: Incorrect because convertible preference shares allow investors to earn a higher dividend than if they invested in the company's common shares.
answerFeedback.f50b11ec-4800-468c-9b4c-f4243c6c1269: Correct because convertible preference shares allow investors the opportunity to share in the profits of the company.

choices.itemBody: A. are more volatile than the underlying common shares.
B. pay lower dividends than the underlying common shares.
C. allow investors to share in the underlying company's profits after conversion.

entry.title: CFA0164-Q1

feedback.neutral: C is correct. The company is not obligated to make dividend payments. It is at the discretion of the company whether or not it chooses to pay dividends.

entry.itemBody: Which of the following is not a characteristic of common equity?

choices.itemBody: A. It represents an ownership interest in the company.
B. Shareholders participate in the decision-making process.
C. The company is obligated to make periodic dividend payments.

entry.title: CFA0164-Q2

feedback.neutral: B is correct. Statutory voting is the type of equity voting right that grants one vote per share owned.

entry.itemBody: The type of equity voting right that grants one vote for each share of equity owned is referred to as:

choices.itemBody: A. proxy voting.
B. statutory voting.
C. cumulative voting.

entry.title: CFA0164-Q3

feedback.neutral: A is correct. Preference shares do not have to be either callable or putable.

entry.itemBody: All of the following are characteristics of preference shares except:

choices.itemBody: A. They are either callable or putable.
B. They generally do not have voting rights.
C. They do not share in the operating performance of the company.

entry.title: CFA0164-Q4

feedback.neutral: C is correct. Participating preference shares entitle shareholders to receive an additional dividend if the company’s profits exceed a pre-determined level.

entry.itemBody: Participating preference shares entitle shareholders to:

choices.itemBody: A. participate in the decision-making process of the company.
B. convert their shares into a specified number of common shares.
C. receive an additional dividend if the company’s profits exceed a pre-determined level.

entry.title: CFA0164-Q5

feedback.neutral: B is correct. Private equity securities do not have market-determined quoted prices.

entry.itemBody: Which of the following statements about private equity securities is incorrect?

choices.itemBody: A. They cannot be sold on secondary markets.
B. They have market-determined quoted prices.
C. They are primarily issued to institutional investors.

entry.title: CFA0164-Q6

feedback.neutral: C is correct. Venture capital investments can be used to provide mezzanine financing to companies in their early stage of development.

entry.itemBody: Venture capital investments:

choices.itemBody: A. can be publicly traded.
B. do not require a long-term commitment of funds.
C. provide mezzanine financing to early-stage companies.

entry.title: CFA0164-Q7

feedback.neutral: B is correct. Regulatory and investor relations costs are lower for private equity firms than for public firms. There are no stock exchange, regulatory, or shareholder involvements with private equity, whereas for public firms these costs can be high.

entry.itemBody: Which of the following statements most accurately describes one difference between private and public equity firms?

choices.itemBody: A. Private equity firms are focused more on short-term results than public firms.
B. Private equity firms’ regulatory and investor relations operations are less costly than those of public firms.
C. Private equity firms are incentivized to be more open with investors about governance and compensation than public firms.

entry.title: CFA0164-Q8

feedback.neutral: C is correct. The trends in emerging markets have not led to the stability of foreign exchange markets.

entry.itemBody: Emerging markets have benefited from recent trends in international markets. Which of the following has not been a benefit of these trends?

choices.itemBody: A. Emerging market companies do not have to worry about a lack of liquidity in their home equity markets.
B. Emerging market companies have found it easier to raise capital in the markets of developed countries.
C. Emerging market companies have benefited from the stability of foreign exchange markets.

entry.title: CFA0164-Q9

feedback.neutral: A is correct. In an unsponsored DR, the depository bank owns the voting rights to the shares. The bank purchases the shares, places them into a trust, and then sells shares in the trust—not the underlying shares—in other markets.

entry.itemBody: When investing in unsponsored depository receipts, the voting rights to the shares in the trust belong to:

choices.itemBody: A. the depository bank.
B. the investors in the depository receipts.
C. the issuer of the shares held in the trust.

entry.title: CFA0164-Q10

feedback.neutral: A is correct. The listing fees on Level III sponsored ADRs are high.

entry.itemBody: With respect to Level III sponsored ADRs, which of the following is least likely to be accurate? They:

choices.itemBody: A. have low listing fees.
B. are traded on the NYSE, NASDAQ, and AMEX.
C. are used to raise equity capital in US markets.

entry.title: CFA0164-Q11

feedback.neutral: C is correct. An ETF is used to gain exposure to a basket of securities (equity, fixed income, commodity futures, etc.).

entry.itemBody: A basket of listed depository receipts, or an exchange-traded fund, would most likely be used for:

choices.itemBody: A. gaining exposure to a single equity.
B. hedging exposure to a single equity.
C. gaining exposure to multiple equities.

entry.title: CFA0164-Q12

feedback.neutral: A is correct. The formula states Rt = (Pt – Pt –1 + Dt )/Pt –1. Therefore, total return = (42 – 50 + 2)/50 = –12.0%.

entry.itemBody:
Calculate the total return on a share of equity using the following data:

Purchase price: $50

Sale price: $42

Dividend paid during holding period: $2

entry.title: CFA0164-Q13

feedback.neutral: A is correct. The depreciated value of the euro will create an additional loss in the form of currency return that is lower than the ETF’s return.

entry.itemBody: If a US-based investor purchases a euro-denominated ETF and the euro subsequently depreciates in value relative to the dollar, the investor will have a total return that is:

choices.itemBody: A. lower than the ETF’s total return.
B. higher than the ETF’s total return.
C. the same as the ETF’s total return.

entry.title: CFA0164-Q14

feedback.neutral: C is correct. Some equity securities do not pay dividends, and therefore the standard deviation of dividends cannot be used to measure the risk of all equity securities.

entry.itemBody: Which of the following is incorrect about the risk of an equity security? The risk of an equity security is:

choices.itemBody: A. based on the uncertainty of its cash flows.
B. based on the uncertainty of its future price.
C. measured using the standard deviation of its dividends.

entry.title: CFA0164-Q15

feedback.neutral: A is correct. Putable shares, whether common or preference, give the investor the option to sell the shares back to the issuer at a pre-determined price. This pre-determined price creates a floor for the share’s price that reduces the uncertainty of future cash flows for the investor (i.e., lowers risk relative to the other two types of shares listed).

entry.itemBody: From an investor’s point of view, which of the following equity securities is the least risky?

choices.itemBody: A. Putable preference shares.
B. Callable preference shares.
C. Non-callable preference shares.

entry.title: CFA0164-Q16

feedback.neutral: C is correct. Issuing shares in the primary (and secondary) market reduces a company’s return on equity because it increases the total amount of equity capital invested in the company (i.e., the denominator in the ROE formula).

entry.itemBody: Which of the following is least likely to be a reason for a company to issue equity securities on the primary market?

choices.itemBody: A. To raise capital.
B. To increase liquidity.
C. To increase return on equity.

entry.title: CFA0164-Q17

feedback.neutral: C is correct. Capital is raised to ensure the company’s existence only when it is required. It is not a typical goal of raising capital.

entry.itemBody: Which of the following is not a primary goal of raising equity capital?

choices.itemBody: A. To finance the purchase of long-lived assets.
B. To finance the company’s revenue-generating activities.
C. To ensure that the company continues as a going concern.

entry.title: CFA0164-Q18

feedback.neutral: A is correct. A company’s book value increases when a company retains its net income.

entry.itemBody: Which of the following statements is most accurate in describing a company’s book value?

choices.itemBody: A. Book value increases when a company retains its net income.
B. Book value is usually equal to the company’s market value.
C. The ultimate goal of management is to maximize book value.

entry.title: CFA0164-Q19

feedback.neutral: A is correct. The book value of the company is equal to total assets minus total liabilities, which is €12,000,000 – €7,500,000 = €4,500,000.

entry.itemBody:
Calculate the book value of a company using the following information:

Number of shares outstanding 100,000
Price per share €52
Total assets €12,000,000
Total liabilities €7,500,000
Net Income €2,000,000

entry.title: CFA0164-Q20

feedback.neutral: A is correct. A company’s market value is affected by management’s decisions. Management’s decisions can directly affect the company’s book value, which can then affect its market value.

entry.itemBody: Which of the following statements is least accurate in describing a company’s market value?

choices.itemBody: A. Management’s decisions do not influence the company’s market value.
B. Increases in book value may not be reflected in the company’s market value.
C. Market value reflects the collective and differing expectations of investors.

entry.title: CFA0164-Q21

feedback.neutral: B is correct. A company’s ROE is calculated as (NI t /BVE t –1). The BVE t –1 is equal to the beginning total assets minus the beginning total liabilities, which equals £50,000,000 – £35,000,000 = £15,000,000. Therefore, ROE = £2,000,000/£15,000,000 = 13.3%.

entry.itemBody:
Calculate the return on equity (ROE) of a stable company using the following data:

Total sales £2,500,000
Net income £2,000,000
Beginning of year total assets £50,000,000
Beginning of year total liabilities £35,000,000
Number of shares outstanding at the end of the year 1,000,000
Price per share at the end of the year £20

entry.title: CFA0164-Q22

feedback.neutral: C is correct. A company’s ROE will increase if it issues debt to repurchase outstanding shares of equity.

entry.itemBody: Holding all other factors constant, which of the following situations will most likely lead to an increase in a company’s return on equity?

choices.itemBody: A. The market price of the company’s shares increases.
B. Net income increases at a slower rate than shareholders’ equity.
C. The company issues debt to repurchase outstanding shares of equity.

entry.title: CFA0164-Q23

feedback.neutral: B is correct. The cost of equity is not easily determined. It is dependent on investors’ required rate of return on equity, which reflects the different risk levels of investors and their expectations about the company’s future cash flows.

entry.itemBody: Which of the following measures is the most difficult to estimate?

choices.itemBody: A. The cost of debt.
B. The cost of equity.
C. Investors’ required rate of return on debt.

entry.title: CFA0164-Q24

feedback.neutral: B is correct. Companies try to raise funds at the lowest possible cost. Therefore, cost of equity is used as a proxy for the minimum required rate of return.

entry.itemBody: A company’s cost of equity is often used as a proxy for investors’:

choices.itemBody: A. average required rate of return.
B. minimum required rate of return.
C. maximum required rate of return.

entry.title: ITEM_20170516076
entry.itemBody: The voting rights of an unsponsored depository receipt (DR) belong to the:

answerFeedback.a13b9edf-2174-4820-b345-4aebd6d7d4d0: Correct. In the case of unsponsored DRs, the depository bank, not the investors in the DR, retains the voting rights.
answerFeedback.b7477d3a-d618-409e-bcb0-09c1081a6fee: Incorrect because the foreign firm does not maintain voting rights with DRs.
answerFeedback.ffe52418-e5de-4bc2-8e56-656cf44ca706: Incorrect because investors in sponsored DRs have the same rights as the direct owners of the common shares.

choices.itemBody: A. depository bank.
B. direct owners of the foreign common shares.
C. foreign company whose shares are held by the depository.

entry.title: ITEM_20170516088
entry.itemBody: Firms with which of the following characteristics are most likely candidates for a management buyout (MBO)?

answerFeedback.1c1fec8b-3ea0-49bb-bf8c-1f70dfd78c22: Correct. Companies with large amounts of undervalued assets (which can be sold to reduce debt) that generate high levels of cash flow (which are used to make interest and principal payments on the debt) are likely candidates for MBO transactions.
answerFeedback.3877f87d-d044-4aa4-9a37-be2c1d421da4: Incorrect. Companies with low levels of cash flow are not preferred candidates for MBO.
answerFeedback.5d4d28a7-88a1-4060-bc3f-4d46938bf261: Incorrect. A high dividend payout ratio is not a preferred characteristic for MBO.

choices.itemBody: A. Firms with low levels of cash flow
B. Firms with high dividend payout ratios
C. Firms with large amounts of undervalued assets

entry.title: ITEM_20170516005
entry.itemBody: The advantages to an investor owning convertible preference shares of a company most likely include:

answerFeedback.60eceb80-e44d-4f4e-8bbb-f1a2b149ef68: Incorrect. Preference dividends are fixed but, unlike interest payment on debt, they are not contractual obligations of the company.
answerFeedback.611cf35a-6892-445b-98e6-dd22585e8ce4: Incorrect. An opportunity to receive additional dividend if the company’s profits exceed a pre-specified level is the benefit that accrues to the holders of participating preferred shares, not convertible preference shareholders.
answerFeedback.9edd30d4-c20c-4149-80dc-913a70fea711: Correct. Convertible preference shares tend to exhibit less price volatility than the underlying common shares because the dividend payments are known and more stable.

choices.itemBody: A. less price volatility than the underlying common shares.
B. preference dividends that are fixed contractual obligations of the company.
C. an opportunity to receive additional dividends if the company’s profits exceed a pre-specified level.

entry.title: ITEM_20170516006
entry.itemBody: Returns from a depository receipt are least likely affected by which of the following factors?

answerFeedback.11dc13c1-b8e0-459c-ac8a-4632965a2db7: Incorrect. The price of each depository receipt (and, in turn, returns) will be affected by such factors as company fundamentals, market conditions, analysts’ recommendations, and exchange rate movements.
answerFeedback.a55ec7c1-ef84-476f-adda-fd524d1d7b82: Incorrect. The price of each depository receipt (and, in turn, returns) will be affected by such factors as company fundamentals, market conditions, analysts’ recommendations, and exchange rate movements.
answerFeedback.e2d963bb-2d72-4aea-8a78-ab57a6ca6443: Correct. The price of each depository receipt (and, in turn, returns) will be affected by factors that affect the price of the underlying shares—such as company fundamentals, market conditions, analysts’ recommendations, and exchange rate movements. The number of depository receipts issued affects their price but does not affect the returns.

choices.itemBody: A. Exchange rate movements
B. Analysts’ recommendations
C. Number of depository receipts

entry.title: ITEM_20170516067
entry.itemBody: Participating preference shares are least likely to entitle the shareholders to participate in:

answerFeedback.b1a888c1-3ce2-401c-bd7a-22a4c8c92e2d: Correct. Participating preference shares do not entitle the shareholders to participate in corporate decisions through voting rights. But they do entitle them to (1) an additional dividend if the company’s profits exceed a prespecified level and (2) additional distribution of the company’s assets upon liquidation, above the par.
answerFeedback.ca0b384c-12a1-4ab0-8456-bf0264010ac7: Incorrect. Participating preference shares entitle the shareholders to participate in additional dividend if the company’s profits exceed a pre-specific level.
answerFeedback.cd78f393-6f14-46e9-899b-a0eba8f5e8c9: Incorrect. Participating preference shares entitle the shareholders to participate in additional distribution of the company’s assets upon liquidation, above the par.

choices.itemBody: A. corporate decisions through voting rights.
B. additional distribution of the company’s assets upon liquidation.
C. additional dividends if the company’s profits exceed a predetermined level.

entry.title: ITEM_20170516083
entry.itemBody: For a US investor, which of the following statements concerning investing in depository receipts (DRs) is least accurate?

answerFeedback.43369c06-63db-4c8d-a621-1e4c8f28a5bb: Correct. Investors of unsponsored DRs would not have the same voting rights as the direct owners of common shares because the depository bank retains the voting rights.
answerFeedback.a2addbeb-7c98-4ee5-8ec3-5c5f94ce19bc: Incorrect because it is an accurate statement. The DRs trading on multiple exchanges could experience short-term valuation discrepancies, potentially giving rise to a quick arbitrage profit opportunity for astute traders to exploit. The price of each DR will be affected by factors that affect the price of the underlying shares and exchange rate movements.
answerFeedback.f68956b2-31f6-43a5-ab80-9df41be9d1c3: Incorrect because it is an accurate statement. Sponsored DRs are subject to greater reporting requirements than unsponsored DRs. In the United States, sponsored DRs must be registered with the SEC.

choices.itemBody: A. Investing in DRs could provide arbitrage opportunities and entail currency risk.
B. Sponsored DRs are subject to greater reporting requirements than unsponsored DRs.
C. Investors in unsponsored DRs would have the same voting rights as the direct owners of common shares.

entry.title: ITEM_20170516084
entry.itemBody: Which of the following statements is most accurate?

answerFeedback.8a466b1f-6f94-405d-bccd-ec22afe0fc4f: Incorrect. Convertible preference shares are less volatile and less risky than the underlying common shares because the dividend payments are known and more stable.
answerFeedback.985e924a-cab4-479e-8223-343117280ce2: Correct. The put option feature facilitates raising capital because the shares are more appealing to investors. As such, it provides a benefit to the issuing company. It also helps investors limit their potential losses because they can sell the shares back to the issuing company if the market price falls below the pre-specified put price. Therefore, putable common shares are beneficial to both the issuing company and the investors.
answerFeedback.de878e6d-4493-4218-994f-15d8b9d57fc7: Incorrect. Investors owning a small number of common shares would prefer cumulative voting, not statutory voting. Cumulative voting allows the investor to cast all votes in favor of a single candidate thereby increasing the chance of having her preferred candidate elected.

choices.itemBody: A. Putable common shares provide benefits to both the issuing company and investors.
B. Convertible preference shares are more volatile and riskier than the underlying common shares.
C. Investors owning a small number of common shares would prefer statutory voting to cumulative voting.

entry.title: ITEM_20170516085
entry.itemBody: Which of the following is most accurate concerning key characteristics of different types of preference shares?

answerFeedback.287dd94f-0697-46a7-a839-96e6368be4d7: Correct. Preference shares have characteristics of both debt securities and common shares. Similar to interest payments on debt securities, the dividends on preference shares are fixed but not contractual obligations. Similar to common shares, preference shares can be perpetual and can pay dividends indefinitely.
answerFeedback.d3a1d6d5-662e-4131-aed5-78551313cd67: Incorrect. The price of convertible preference shares is less volatile than their underlying common shares because there is less uncertainty about future cash flows as dividend payments are known and more stable. In addition, convertible preference shares allow investors the opportunity to share in the profits of the company.
answerFeedback.d88236e3-44a9-454f-8744-deb9451cb2f7: Incorrect. Both common and preference shareholders are owners of the company and will have claims on assets after liabilities to all creditors including bondholders have been completely paid. Preference shareholders rank before common shareholders but after bondholders to receive net distributions.

choices.itemBody: A. Preference shares have characteristics of both debt and equity securities.
B. Preference shareholders rank above subordinated bondholders with respect to claims on the company’s net assets upon liquidation.
C. The price of convertible preference shares tends to be more volatile than their underlying common shares because they do not allow investors to share in profits of the company.

entry.title: ITEM_20170516086
entry.itemBody: The type of voting in board elections that is most beneficial to shareholders with a small number of shares is best described as:

answerFeedback.72006399-1f6a-42df-98e4-9a3cd6fac6f8: Correct. Cumulative voting allows shareholders to direct their total voting rights to specific candidates, as opposed to having to allocate their voting rights evenly among all candidates. Thus, applying all of the votes to one candidate provides the opportunity for a higher level of representation on the board than would be allowed under statutory voting.
answerFeedback.b13b0596-4c5b-4bb3-916c-46a35c69c119: Incorrect. In statutory voting, votes cannot be cast on a cumulative basis thereby making it disadvantageous to investors with small number of shares to elect their preferred candidate(s) to the board.
answerFeedback.b9fc3df4-f93c-44c9-9d92-e33b44bfd490: Incorrect. Voting by proxy allows a designated party—such as another shareholder, a shareholder representative, or management—to vote on the shareholders’ behalf. By itself it does not provide a benefit to small investors in board elections.

choices.itemBody: A. statutory voting.
B. voting by proxy.
C. cumulative voting.

entry.title: ITEM_20170516087
entry.itemBody: A company has issued only one class of common shares, and it does not pay dividends on them. It has also issued two types of non-cumulative preference shares: one that is putable and the other callable. Which of these securities will most likely offer the lowest expected return to the investor?

answerFeedback.a3824341-b7f1-4721-b56c-b4609acae210: Incorrect. Common shares are the most risky, whether or not dividend paying, and are likely to offer the highest expected return. Though these preference shares have non-cumulative dividend feature, preference shareholders will receive priority if the company is liquidated.
answerFeedback.ac7e4267-e650-43c1-894e-ab1bdd752426: Incorrect. Callable preference shares are more risky than their putable counterparts and so they are likely to offer higher expected returns than putable preference shares.
answerFeedback.e8af89a7-cd44-4ffd-89ff-30125f562a62: Correct. Putable preference shares are less risky than their callable counterparts. They give the investor the option to put the shares back to the company. Because of the lower risk, they will provide a lower expected rate of return. Common shares are the most risky, whether or not they are dividend paying, and are likely to offer the highest expected return.

choices.itemBody: A. Common shares
B. Putable preference shares
C. Callable preference shares

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-Equity-Coorey-03
entry.itemBody: A company's net income available to ordinary shareholders divided by the average total book value of equity is best described as the:

answerFeedback.57e22bd8-9e63-40fb-8f0d-28373682cc8f: Incorrect because companies try to raise capital at the lowest possible cost, [and] the company’s cost of equity is often used as a proxy for the investors’ minimum required rate of return.
answerFeedback.add3456c-ab20-4000-bf96-5341c7031a3f: Correct because return on equity (ROE) is computed as net income available to ordinary shareholders (i.e., after preferred dividends have been deducted) divided by the average total book value of equity (BVE).
answerFeedback.ce9aa759-d701-486c-9669-1504e01ed7da: Incorrect because intrinsic value refers to the true value of an asset. And a primary means to estimate a company’s true or intrinsic value is the present value of its future projected cash flows.

choices.itemBody: A. company's intrinsic value.
B. company's return on equity.
C. minimum required rate of return of investors in the company's equity.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-Equity-Islam-06
entry.itemBody: Convertible preference shares most likely:

answerFeedback.5c9ad350-ed61-4090-8e6a-e7a4500193d3: Correct because convertible preference shares allow investors to benefit from a rise in the price of the common shares through the conversion option.
answerFeedback.88861d09-0d3b-4964-b693-c8729759da19: Incorrect because the use of convertible preference shares is a popular financing option in venture capital and private equity transactions in which the issuing companies are considered to be of higher risk and when it may be years before the issuing company 'goes public' (i.e., issues common shares to the public).
answerFeedback.a898a90d-ed6c-41a9-9e87-8e43255968da: Incorrect because preference shares (or preferred stock) rank above common shares with respect to the payment of dividends and the distribution of the company’s net assets upon liquidation. Their [convertible preference shares'] price is less volatile than the underlying common shares because the dividend payments are known and more stable.

choices.itemBody: A. are riskier than the underlying common shares for investors.
B. allow investors to benefit from a rise in the price of the common shares.
C. are issued primarily by companies of lower risk and used as a financing option.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-Equity-Horvath-07
entry.itemBody: Preference shares most likely rank above common shares with respect to:

answerFeedback.02213b74-3b7e-49b1-a3f7-b64e0731dc74: Incorrect because preference shares do not have any voting rights, unless explicitly allowed for at issuance.
answerFeedback.92b90eba-3c32-424c-b4c4-70fa1e7314d3: Correct because preference shares (or preferred stock) rank above common shares with respect to the payment of dividends and the distribution of the company’s net assets upon liquidation.
answerFeedback.dc38b5c3-3932-4904-b14f-d025f658f34d: Incorrect because preference shareholders generally do not share in the operating performance of the company.

choices.itemBody: A. voting rights.
B. sharing in the operating performance of the company.
C. the distribution of the company’s net assets upon liquidation.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-Equity-McDonald-03
entry.itemBody: Private equity securities most likely:

answerFeedback.3f3375d2-8aff-4b32-9144-3e5417b79306: Incorrect because financial statements and other important information needed to determine the fair value of private equity securities may be difficult to obtain because the issuing companies are typically not required by regulatory authorities to publish this information.
answerFeedback.84f000a0-81c1-44f5-8a1a-baacdc8b0741: Incorrect because private equity securities are issued primarily to institutional investors via non-public offerings, such as private placements. Because they are not listed on public exchanges, there is no active secondary market for these securities.
answerFeedback.b738b44d-b8fa-4a3f-90eb-3aa9610fea9d: Correct because private equity securities do not have “market determined” quoted prices, are highly illiquid, and require negotiations between investors in order to be traded.

choices.itemBody: A. are listed on public exchanges.
B. are illiquid and difficult to trade.
C. have easily available financial information.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-Equity-McDonald-04
entry.itemBody: Preference shares are less risky than common shares because preference shares have:

answerFeedback.47cfe11a-ec3f-429c-9901-dc3ccfba0d60: Incorrect because dividends account for a large portion of the preference shares’ total return. With common shares, however, a larger portion of shareholders’ total return (or all of their total return for non-dividend shares) is based on future price appreciation.
answerFeedback.6ee80d05-21fa-4292-931c-17b3b9839efd: Correct because dividends on preference shares are known and fixed, and they account for a large portion of the preference shares’ total return. Therefore, there is less uncertainty about future cash flows.
answerFeedback.e763fe3f-3ce6-438a-86fc-e0b9c6d5c279: Incorrect because the amount preference shareholders will receive if the company is liquidated is known and fixed as the par (or face) value of their shares. However, there is no guarantee that investors will receive that amount if the company experiences financial difficulty.

choices.itemBody: A. fixed dividends.
B. a guaranteed return if a company is liquidated.
C. a larger portion of total return based on future price return.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-02729
entry.itemBody: All else being equal, which of the following preference share characteristics may contain provisions that entitle shareholders to an additional distribution of the company's assets upon liquidation, above the par value?

answerFeedback.1b682229-8bff-4f25-b3d3-65146885ea4f: Incorrect because the callable feature is not relevant in liquidation because it gives the company the right but not the obligation to buy back shares from investors. A buyback is not likely in liquidation.
answerFeedback.22e995e1-0b98-4423-9b1e-8908b7d76bfb: Correct because of the three characteristics, only the participating characteristic is most directly affected by liquidation of the company. Participating preference shares can also contain provisions that entitle shareholders to an additional distribution of the company's assets upon liquidation, above the par (or face) value of the preference shares.
answerFeedback.2c328d51-ad3e-46fb-a789-380a3d6afc08: Incorrect because the cumulative feature only requires dividends to be paid for preference shares before common dividends are paid. The payment of common dividends is not likely in liquidation and thus the cumulative characteristic is not likely to be exercised.

choices.itemBody: A. Callable
B. Cumulative
C. Participating

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-08210
entry.itemBody: A company's management is most likely able to directly influence the company's:

answerFeedback.4e620b11-e54b-4d5e-abbc-792dc375221d: Correct because management's decisions directly influence a company's net income, they also directly influence its book value of equity.
answerFeedback.5988ac35-2f28-48f0-a252-96b8ef32e36c: Incorrect because a company's intrinsic value can only be estimated because it is impossible to predict the amount and timing of its future cash flows. As such, this is not a value that management has direct control over.
answerFeedback.5c26a586-059f-4103-9743-e1dfd12bcc68: Incorrect because management actions can only indirectly affect the market value of its equity.  The market value of the company's equity reflects the collective and differing expectations of investors concerning the amount, timing, and uncertainty of the company's future cash flows.

choices.itemBody: A. book value.
B. market value.
C. intrinsic value.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020A-Equity-Islam-01
entry.itemBody: Convertible preference shares:

answerFeedback.02016422-613f-4d26-bddc-652fe4cf53af: Incorrect because convertible preference shares allow investors to benefit from a rise in the price of the common shares through the conversion option.
answerFeedback.352a986b-51cd-4b75-b625-d30dfacbcb2b: Correct because the use of convertible preference shares is a popular financing option in venture capital and private equity transactions in which the issuing companies are considered to be of higher risk and when it may be years before the issuing company 'goes public' (i.e., issues common shares to the public).
answerFeedback.529b8367-d484-44c2-b8f7-ce953a5ac348: Incorrect because the convertible preference shares' price is less volatile than the underlying common shares because the dividend payments are known and more stable.

choices.itemBody: A. are popular in financing venture capital and private equity transactions.
B. are subject to more price volatility than the underlying common shares.
C. do not increase in value due to an increase in price of the underlying common shares.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020B-Equity-Erickson-07
entry.itemBody:
An investor gathers the following data regarding three stocks:

Stock Expected Rate of Return Investor's Required Rate of Return
1 9% 9%
2 13% 11%
3 15% 16%

All else being equal, the investor should purchase:

answerFeedback.7aada192-6b1a-41b2-800a-dfca9a974cf1: Correct because the expected rate of return for Stock 2 exceeds the investor's required rate of return. In other words, the cost of equity can be thought of as the minimum expected rate of return that a company must offer its investors to purchase its shares in the primary market and to maintain its share price in the secondary market. If this expected rate of return is not maintained in the secondary market, then the share price will adjust so that it meets the minimum required rate of return demanded by investors. For example, if investors require a higher rate of return on equity than the company’s cost of equity, they would sell their shares and invest their funds elsewhere resulting in a decline in the company’s share price.
answerFeedback.7d9e160a-e3c4-4db6-8e0a-295016dee8ab: Incorrect because the expected rate of return for Stock 3 is below the investor's required rate of return. If investors require a higher rate of return on equity than the company’s cost of equity, they would sell their shares and invest their funds elsewhere resulting in a decline in the company’s share price.
answerFeedback.b15e0920-3a61-4d63-afe4-b2039b523d05: Incorrect because the expected rate of return for Stock 1 is equal to the investor's required rate of return. If investors require a higher rate of return on equity than the company’s cost of equity, they would sell their shares and invest their funds elsewhere resulting in a decline in the company’s share price.

choices.itemBody: A. Stock 1.
B. Stock 2.
C. Stock 3.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-01996
entry.itemBody: In contrast to a public company, a company that has gone private most likely:

answerFeedback.72b5498f-6e84-487f-afad-917e3eaa1ae2: Incorrect because private companies have lower regulatory costs: by 'going private,' management can adopt a more long-term focus and can eliminate certain costs that are necessary to operate a publicly traded company — such as the cost of meeting regulatory and stock exchange requirements.
answerFeedback.79e98455-f608-4d78-9349-c64a18bcf8d8: Incorrect because private companies focus more on long-term results: the move to longer holding periods has given private equity investors the opportunity to more effectively and patiently address any underlying operational issues facing the company and to better manage it for long-term value creation.
answerFeedback.961c7542-1e22-4137-be1d-cf4c9464948b: Correct because there is no active secondary market for equity of private companies and the shares require negotiations between investors in order to be traded. This is in contrast to public companies, which have secondary markets for trading their equity.

choices.itemBody: A. faces greater regulatory costs.
B. focuses more on short-term results.
C. lacks an active secondary market for its equity.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-05864
entry.itemBody: All else being equal, the preference share with the lowest certainty of future cash flows and the greatest potential risk for investors is most likely:

answerFeedback.061270db-8dee-470b-bc13-53505f59afe6: Incorrect because callable common or preference shares are riskier than their non-callable counterparts because the issuer has the option to redeem the shares at a pre-determined price. Non-callable shares do not expose the investor to the greatest potential risk. Also, dividends on cumulative preference shares accrue so that if the company decides not to pay a dividend in one or more periods, the unpaid dividends accrue. This feature provides the investor with a certainty of future cash flows.
answerFeedback.3e7ba02d-6369-4a21-a0e8-7b30345e2ece: Correct because a callable preference share with non-cumulative dividends has greater uncertainty of cash flows than a putable preference share with non-cumulative dividends. From an investor's point of view, putable common or preference shares are less risky than their callable or non-callable counterparts.  The callable preference share with non-cumulative dividends has greater uncertainty of cash flows than the non-callable preference share with cumulative dividends on the basis of both its callable feature, as previously described, and its non-cumulative feature. Cumulative preference shares have lower risk than non-cumulative preference shares.
answerFeedback.a819e16b-b3fe-4b3d-9695-7500894ff74a: Incorrect because from an investor's point of view, putable common or preference shares are less risky than their callable or non-callable counterparts. They do not expose the investor to the greatest potential risk. Also, dividends on cumulative preference shares accrue so that if the company decides not to pay a dividend in one or more periods, the unpaid dividends accrue. This feature provides the investor with a greater certainty of future cash flows. The non-cumulative feature provides the investor with greater uncertainty of future cash flows.

choices.itemBody: A. putable with non-cumulative dividends.
B. non-callable with cumulative dividends.
C. callable with non-cumulative dividends.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-Equity-Islam-07
entry.itemBody: Sponsored depository receipts most likely differ from unsponsored ones in terms of whether:

answerFeedback.ccdae302-cc8b-41e3-b19d-cdc2a261f486: Incorrect because a depository receipt (DR) (sponsored or unsponsored) is a security that trades like an ordinary share on a local exchange and represents an economic interest in a foreign company. The price of each DR will be affected by factors that affect the price of the underlying shares, such as company fundamentals, market conditions, analysts’ recommendations, and exchange rate movements.
answerFeedback.e542e3b5-0ac6-49c9-a882-9846d4145f97: Correct because a sponsored DR is when the foreign company whose shares are held by the depository has a direct involvement in the issuance of the receipts. Investors in sponsored DRs have the same rights as the direct owners of the common shares (e.g., the right to vote and the right to receive dividends). In contrast, with an unsponsored DR, the underlying foreign company has no involvement with the issuance of the receipts. Instead, the depository purchases the foreign company’s shares in its domestic market and then issues the receipts through brokerage firms in the depository’s local market. In this case, the depository bank, not the investors in the DR, retains the voting rights.
answerFeedback.f6e7b456-e790-45c3-bb9c-c24966ecfece: Incorrect because a depository receipt (DR) (sponsored or unsponsored) is a security that trades like an ordinary share on a local exchange and represents an economic interest in a foreign company.

choices.itemBody: A. investors have voting rights.
B. they are traded on exchanges.
C. their prices are affected by exchange rate movements.
